facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 806 of 1964 was filed.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated July 13, 1962 of Madras High Court in Appeal No. 347 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated July 13, 1962, of the Madras High Court in Appeal No. 347 of 1958.

facts.text: Suit brought by Nagappa Chettiar (respondent No. 1) against Villiammi Achi (appellant) and Nachiammai Achi (dead, represented by legal representative).

anchor.surface_text: A suit was brought by Nagappa Chettiar, respondent No. 1  hereinafter referred to as the respondent  against Villiammi Achi appellant and Nachiammai Achi number dead and represented by her legal representative.

facts.text: Respondent claimed two-thirds share of properties left by his father Pallaniappa and prayed for separate possession after partition.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent claimed two-thirds share of the properties left by his father, Pallaniappa and prayed for a decree for separate possession of that share after partition.

facts.text: Respondent is the adopted son of Pallaniappa, adopted in 1941.

anchor.surface_text: The facts on which this claim was based are number number in dispute and are these. The respondent is the adopted son of Pallaniappa. having been adopted in 1941.

facts.text: Appellant is the widow of Pallaniappa.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the widow of Pallaniappa and Nachiammai Achi was Pallaniappas mother.

facts.text: Nachiammai Achi was Pallaniappa's mother.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the widow of Pallaniappa and Nachiammai Achi was Pallaniappas mother.

facts.text: Pallaniappa's father, Nagappa, had considerable properties and made a will on June 10, 1934.

anchor.surface_text: Pallaniappas father also named Nagappa had companysiderable properties. This Nagappa made a will on June 10, 1934 by which after making certain dis- positions,

facts.text: Nagappa's will gave residue of property absolutely to Pallaniappa and appointed him executor.

anchor.surface_text: by which after making certain dis- positions, in favour of certain persons including his own wife he gave the residue of his property absolutely to Pallaniappa and appointed him as the executor of the will.

facts.text: Nagappa died in July 1934.

anchor.surface_text: After Nagappas death in July 1934 Pallaniappa obtained probate of the will

facts.text: Pallaniappa obtained probate of the will and came into possession of the residue after providing for legacies.

anchor.surface_text: Pallaniappa obtained probate of the will and after providing for the legacies to others as indicated therein came into possession of the residue of the property.

facts.text: In trial court, dispute whether Pallaniappa and father were joint Hindu family members and properties joint family properties.

anchor.surface_text: In the trial companyrt there was a dispute between the parties whether Pallaniappa and his father were members of a joint Hindu family and whether properties left by Pallaniappas father were the joint family properties of both.

facts.text: All properties left by Pallaniappa's father were joint family properties of Pallaniappa and his father, acquirable by survivorship; finding upheld by High Court, not now in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: But it has been found that all the properties left by Pallaniappas father were joint family properties of Pallaniappa and his father which Pallaniappa companyld acquire by survivorship on his fathers death. This finding was upheld by the High Court and is number number in dispute.

facts.text: Pallaniappa died on September 16, 1956 after Hindu Succession Act, 1956 came into force.

anchor.surface_text: Pallaniappa died. on September 16, 1956 after the Hindu Succession Act,  No. 30 of 1956  came into force.

facts.text: Trial court decreed suit with preliminary decree: two-thirds to respondent, one-sixth each to appellant and mother of Pallaniappa.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt accepted the case put forward on behalf of the respondent and decreed the suit passing a preliminary decree giving two-thirds share to the respondent and one-sixth each to the appellant,, and the mother of Pallaniappa.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to High Court, appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then appealed to the High Court. The High Court dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: High Court refused certificate to appeal to Supreme Court; appellant obtained special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court having refused to grant a certificate to appeal to this Court, the appellant applied for and obtained special leave from this Court

facts.text: Appellant's case: Pallaniappa's conduct in obtaining probate amounted to election, became absolute owner; respondent not acquire interest by adoption in 1941.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the appellant was that even though the properties left by Pallaniappas father were joint family properties which MISup.CI/67-15 Pallaniappa companyld acquire by survivorship, the companyduct of Pallaniappa in obtaining probate of the will and carrying out its terms amounted to election and thereafter Pallaniappa became absolute owner of the residue of the properties bequeathed to him by the will. The companysequence of this was that when Pallaniappa adopted the respondent in 1941 long after he had become -the absolute owner of the properties, the respondent acquired numberinterest in the properties left by his grand-father by virtue of the adoption.

facts.text: Respondent's case: no election by Pallaniappa; even if election, respondent not bound as acquired independent interest upon adoption.

anchor.surface_text: The reply on behalf of the respondent to this companytention was two-fold. In the first place, it was urged that there was numberquestion of election even by Pallaniappa in this case and s. 180 of the Indian Succession Act would number apply. It was further urged that even assuming that there companyld be election by Pallaniappa the respondent would number be bound by that election as the property left by his grandfather was joint family property and the respondent would acquire interest therein as soon is he was adopted by Pallaniappa,

facts.text: Respondent's case: after adoption, Pallaniappa threw entire property into family hotch-pot, became joint family property by blending.

anchor.surface_text: In the second place the respondents case was that in any case after his adoption Pallaniappa threw the ,entire property into the family hotch-pot and therefore it became joint family property by blending.

facts.text: High Court held no election by Pallaniappa as he had title by survivorship irrespective of will.

anchor.surface_text: On the question of election, the High Court held that as Pallaniappa and his father were members of a joint Hindu family and as the entire property left by Pallanippas father was joint family property, Pallaniappa had interest in the residue as a survivor and in companysequence there was numberquestion of election by Pallaniappa for all the property he got by will would have companye to him by survivorship.

facts.text: High Court held respondent's claim independent of father, not bound by any election.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also held that in any case the claim of the respondent as a member of the joint family was number under his father but independent of him and therefore the respondent would number be bound-, even if Pallaniappa were held to have made an election.

facts.text: High Court found in favour of respondent on throwing into hotch-pot.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also found in favour of the respondent on the question whether the property was thrown into family hotch-pot after the adoption of the respondent
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated July 13, 1962, of the Madras High Court in Appeal No. 347 of 1958.
This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment of the Madras High Court.
The High Court having refused to grant a certificate to appeal to this Court, the appellant applied for and obtained special leave from this Court

arguments.claim: S.180 requires election only where testator disposes of legatee's property and gives legatee benefit otherwise unavailable

anchor.surface_text: Section 180 of the Indian Succession Act which enunciates the doctrine of election as known to English law for this country is in these terms Where a person, by his will professes to dispose of something which he has noright to dispose of, the person to whom the thing belongs shall elect either to confirm such disposition or to dissent from it, and, in the latter case, he shall give up any benefits which may have been provided for him by the will.

arguments.claim: No election where legatee entitled to property anyway independent of will, as here by survivorship

anchor.surface_text: It is urged on behalf of the appellant that s. 180 would apply to the facts of the present case for the property willed by Pallaniappas father was no his which he could will away as it was joint family property in which Pallaniappa who was the residuary legatee had also equal interest. Therefore Pallaniappa had either to confirm the disposition or dissent from it, and his conduct showed that he had confirmed it for he took out probate. Therefore it must be held that after probate was taken out the residue became the absolute property of Pallaniappa and lost its character as joint Hindu family property. Now it is clear from s. 180 that after the legatee elects to dissent from the will he must give up any benefits provided for him by the will. This shows that election under s. 180 would only arise where the legatee derives some benefit from the will to which he would no be entitled except for the will.

arguments.claim: Father's will cannot change joint family property to absolute property of son, depriving grandsons

anchor.surface_text: But even assuming that there was some kind of election by Pallaniappa we cannot see how the nature of the property left by Pallaniappas father would change merely because Pallaniappas father made a will giving the residue absolutely to Pallaniappa and Pallaniappa took out probate of the will. The property being joint family property Pallaniappas father was no entitled to will it away and his making a will would make nodifference to the nature of the property when it came into the hands of Pallaniappa. A father cannot turn joint family property into absolute property of his son by merely making a will, thus depriving sons of the son who might be born thereafter of their right in the joint family property.

arguments.claim: Under Mitakshara, son takes interest equal to father in ancestral property by birth, independent of father

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that the share which a coparcener obtains on partition of ancestral property is ancestral property as regards his male issues. They take an interest in it by birth whether they are in existence at the time of partition or are born subsequently see Hindu Law by Mulla, Thirteenth Edition p. 249, para 223  2   4 . If that is so and the character of the ancestral property does no change so far as -sons are concerned even after partition, we fail to see how that character can change merely because the father makes a will by which he gives the residue of the joint family property  after making certain bequests  to the son. A father in a Mitakshara family has a very limited right to make a will and Pallaniappas father could no make the will disposing of the entire joint family property, though he gave the residue to his son.

arguments.claim: Adopted son acquires interest in joint family property independent of adoptive father upon adoption

anchor.surface_text: Further it is equally well settled that under the Mitakshara law each son upon his birth takes an interest equal to that of his father in ancestral property, whether it be movable or immovable. It is very important to remember that the right which the son takes at his birth in the ancestral property is wholly independent of his father. He does no claim through the father  see Mullas Hindu Law, Thirteenth Edition, p. 251, para 224 . It follows therefore that the character of the property did no change in this case because of the will of Pallaniappas father and it would still be joint family property in the hands of Pallaniappa so far as his male issue was concerned. Further as soon as the respondent was adopted he acquired interest in the joint family property in the hands of Pallaniappa and this interest of his was independent of his father Pallaniappa.

holdings.text: There was no question of election by Pallaniappa under Section 180 of the Indian Succession Act as he was entitled to the entire property by survivorship irrespective of the will.

anchor.surface_text: It is urged on behalf of the appellant that s. 180 would apply to the facts of the present case for the property willed by Pallaniappas father was no his which he could will away as it was joint family property in which Pallaniappa who was the residuary legatee had also equal interest. Therefore Pallaniappa had either to confirm the disposition or dissent from it, and his conduct showed that he had confirmed it for he took out probate. Therefore it must be held that after probate was taken out the residue became the absolute property of Pallaniappa and lost its character as joint Hindu family property. Now it is clear from s. 180 that after the legatee elects to dissent from the will he must give up any benefits provided for him by the will. This shows that election under s. 180 would only arise where the legatee derives some benefit from the will to which he would no be entitled except for the will. In such a case he has to elect whether to confirm the will or dissent from it. But where there is noquestion of the legatee deriving any benefit from the will to which he would no be entitled except for the will, the fact that he confirms the will and accepts what the will provides would no amount to election, for he would have in any case got what the will gave him. Thus election only arises where the legatee has to choose between his own property which might have been willed away to somebody else and the property which belongs to the testator and which the testator has given to the legatee by the will. The matter is brought out in Halsburys Laws of England, Third Edition, Vol. 14, at p. 588, para 1091 in the following words Where a testator by his will purports to give property to A which in fact belongs to B and at the same time out of his own property confers, benefits on B in such cir- cumstances B is no allowed to take the full benefit given him by the will unless he is prepared to carry into effect the whole of the testators dispositions. He is accordingly put to his election to take either under the instrument or against it. If he elects to take under the will he is bound and may be ordered to convey his own property to A if he elects to take against the will and to keep his own property, and so disappoints A, then, he cannot take any benefits under the will without compensating A out of such benefits to the extent of the value of the property of which A is disappointed. Following this principle the High Court held that as the property which the will gave to Pallaniappa would in any case have come to him as a member of the joint family, there was noquestion of election even by Pallaniappa in this case. This view appears to us to be correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of S.180 requires election only when legatee must choose between own property disposed by will and benefit under will; here no benefit beyond survivorship right, confirmed by Halsbury and High Court view.

holdings.text: Even assuming some kind of election by Pallaniappa, the character of the joint family property does not change to absolute property merely because the father made a will giving it absolutely to the son and the son took probate.

anchor.surface_text: But even assuming that there was some kind of election by Pallaniappa we cannot see how the nature of the property left by Pallaniappas father would change merely because Pallaniappas father made a will giving the residue absolutely to Pallaniappa and Pallaniappa took out probate of the will. The property being joint family property Pallaniappas father was no entitled to will it away and his making a will would make nodifference to the nature of the property when it came into the hands of Pallaniappa. A father cannot turn joint family property into absolute property of his son by merely making a will, thus depriving sons of the son who might be born thereafter of their right in the joint family property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Joint family property devolves by survivorship; father lacks power to dispose by will to alter character in hands of son vis-a-vis grandsons; will ineffective to change nature.

holdings.text: Under Mitakshara law, a son's interest in ancestral joint family property arises by birth equal to father's and is wholly independent of the father; a father has limited testamentary power over such property.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that the share which a coparcener obtains on partition of ancestral property is ancestral property as regards his male issues. They take an interest in it by birth whether they are in existence at the time of partition or are born subsequently see Hindu Law by Mulla, Thirteenth Edition p. 249, para 223  2   4 . If that is so and the character of the ancestral property does no change so far as -sons are concerned even after partition, we fail to see how that character can change merely because the father makes a will by which he gives the residue of the joint family property  after making certain bequests  to the son. A father in a Mitakshara family has a very limited right to make a will and Pallaniappas father could no make the will disposing of the entire joint family property, though he gave the residue to his son. We are therefore of opinion,that merely because Pallanappas father made the will and Pallaniappa probably as a dutiful son took out probate and carried out the wishes of his father, the nature of the property could no change and it will be joint family property in the hands of Pallaniappa so far as his male issues are concerned. Further it is equally well settled that under the Mitakshara law each son upon his birth takes an interest equal to that of his father in ancestral property, whether it be movable or immovable. It is very important to remember that the right which the son takes at his birth in the ancestral property is wholly independent of his father. He does no claim through the father  see Mullas Hindu Law, Thirteenth Edition, p. 251, para 224 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cites Mulla's Hindu Law: partition share remains ancestral for sons; son's interest by birth independent; father cannot will away coparcenary property fully.

holdings.text: The adopted son acquires interest in the adoptive father's joint family property immediately upon adoption, independent of the father, and is not bound by any election made by the adoptive father.

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore that the character of the property did no change in this case because of the will of Pallaniappas father and it would still be joint family property in the hands of Pallaniappa so far as his male issue was concerned. Further as soon as the respondent was adopted he acquired interest in the joint family property in the hands of Pallaniappa and this interest of his was independent of his father Pallaniappa. In such circumstances even if Pallaniappa could be said to have made an election there can be noquestion of the respondent being bound by that election, for he is no claiming through his father.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopted son stands in same position as natural son under Mitakshara law; interest independent, not derivative through father.

holdings.text: It is unnecessary to consider whether Pallaniappa threw the property into the family hotchpot after the respondent's adoption.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter, it is unnecessary to consider the question whether Pallaniappa, after the, respondents adoption, threw the property into.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Election issue conclusively resolves in respondent's favour; alternative ground not needed for decision.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the appeal.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court judgment upheld; preliminary decree for partition granting two-thirds share to respondent No.1 upheld as Supreme Court agrees there was no election binding the respondent

anchor.surface_text: It is urged on behalf of the appellant that s. 180 would apply to the facts of the present case for the property willed by Pallaniappas father was no his which he could will away as it was joint family property in which Pallaniappa who was the residuary legatee had also equal interest. Therefore Pallaniappa had either to confirm the disposition or dissent from it, and his conduct showed that he had confirmed it for he took out probate. Therefore it must be held that after probate was taken out the residue became the absolute property of Pallaniappa and lost its character as joint Hindu family property. Now it is clear from s. 180 that after the legatee elects to dissent from the will he must give up any benefits provided for him by the will. This shows that election under s. 180 would only arise where the legatee derives some benefit from the will to which he would no be entitled except for the will. In such a case he has to elect whether to confirm the will or dissent from it. But where there is noquestion of the legatee deriving any benefit from the will to which he would no be entitled except for the will, the fact that he confirms the will and accepts what the will provides would no amount to election, for he would have in any case got what the will gave him. Thus election only arises where the legatee has to choose between his own property which might have been willed away to somebody else and the property which belongs to the testator and which the testator has given to the legatee by the will. The matter is brought out in Halsburys Laws of England, Third Edition, Vol. 14, at p. 588, para 1091 in the following words Where a testator by his will purports to give property to A which in fact belongs to B and at the same time out of his own property confers, benefits on B in such cir- cumstances B is no allowed to take the full benefit given him by the will unless he is prepared to carry into effect the whole of the testators dispositions. He is accordingly put to his election to take either under the instrument or against it. If he elects to take under the will he is bound and may be ordered to convey his own property to A if he elects to take against the will and to keep his own property, and so disappoints A, then, he cannot take any benefits under the will without compensating A out of such benefits to the extent of the value of the property of which A is disappointed. Following this principle the High Court held that as the property which the will gave to Pallaniappa would in any case have come to him as a member of the joint family, there was noquestion of election even by Pallaniappa in this case. This view appears to us to be correct.
The High Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: But even assuming that there was some kind of election by Pallaniappa we cannot see how the nature of the property left by Pallaniappas father would change merely because Pallaniappas father made a will giving the residue absolutely to Pallaniappa and Pallaniappa took out probate of the will. The property being joint family property Pallaniappas father was no entitled to will it away and his making a will would make nodifference to the nature of the property when it came into the hands of Pallaniappa. A father cannot turn joint family property into absolute property of his son by merely making a will, thus depriving sons of the son who might be born thereafter of their right in the joint family property.
The High Court dismissed the appeal.

edges.explanation: h3's explanation of son's independent interest under Mitakshara law addresses why respondent not bound by father's election in i1

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that the share which a coparcener obtains on partition of ancestral property is ancestral property as regards his male issues. They take an interest in it by birth whether they are in existence at the time of partition or are born subsequently see Hindu Law by Mulla, Thirteenth Edition p. 249, para 223  2   4 . If that is so and the character of the ancestral property does no change so far as -sons are concerned even after partition, we fail to see how that character can change merely because the father makes a will by which he gives the residue of the joint family property  after making certain bequests  to the son. A father in a Mitakshara family has a very limited right to make a will and Pallaniappas father could no make the will disposing of the entire joint family property, though he gave the residue to his son. We are therefore of opinion,that merely because Pallanappas father made the will and Pallaniappa probably as a dutiful son took out probate and carried out the wishes of his father, the nature of the property could no change and it will be joint family property in the hands of Pallaniappa so far as his male issues are concerned. Further it is equally well settled that under the Mitakshara law each son upon his birth takes an interest equal to that of his father in ancestral property, whether it be movable or immovable. It is very important to remember that the right which the son takes at his birth in the ancestral property is wholly independent of his father. He does no claim through the father  see Mullas Hindu Law, Thirteenth Edition, p. 251, para 224 .
The High Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore that the character of the property did no change in this case because of the will of Pallaniappas father and it would still be joint family property in the hands of Pallaniappa so far as his male issue was concerned. Further as soon as the respondent was adopted he acquired interest in the joint family property in the hands of Pallaniappa and this interest of his was independent of his father Pallaniappa. In such circumstances even if Pallaniappa could be said to have made an election there can be noquestion of the respondent being bound by that election, for he is no claiming through his father.
The High Court dismissed the appeal.
